titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went this forenoon with Mr: Johnson and his son, to Georgetown, and walk’d round the place and its adjoining neighbourhood.— Engaged the whole stage to Frederick, for Tuesday morning (the day after to-morrow). Mr: & Mrs: Johnson, with their two youngest daughters are to go with us— We all dined at Mr: Madison’s— The company besides ourselves and his family, were Mr: & Miss Steele, and Dr: and Mrs: Thornton— Dr: Thornton was by turns ingenious and humorous, but all the time very talkative— We spent the evening and supp’d at Mr: Hellen’s.

2. Mr: Cranch called to see me this morning— Went with him to Georgetown— Paid a visit to Mr: Harrison the Auditor and to Mr: Pichon, whom I found at home— Carried the letter for my mother to the post-office— Mr and Mrs: Hellen, dined with us, and spent the evening— Employed in preparing for our departure.— Mr: Johnson made me a present of a watch, as a token of his affection.

3. Just after 7 this morning, we left the city in the Frederick-town stage. Mr: and Mrs: Johnson, with their two youngest daughters, Eliza, and Adelaide, accompanied us, and Caroline goes to spent the winter with her sister— We breakfasted at Robb’s, fourteen miles from the city; dined at Shell’s fourteen miles further, and reached Frederic at about 6 in the evening—the last stage was fifteen miles— The whole way, both Mr: Johnson and my child were severely ill, the former with an attack of the gravel, the latter with symptoms resembling a dysentery, which we first discovered yesterday morning, but which we hope is are only the attendants of teething— We put up at Mrs: Kimball’s; Mr Johnson was obliged to go immediately to bed, and send for Dr: Thomas, an eminent physician who came immediately together with Coll: Baker Johnson, my father in Law’s brother— The latter watch’d with him; and for five or six hours he suffered pain of more excessive violence than I ever witness’d— About midnight he began to find some relief, and we retir’d to bed— Dr: Thomas gave my child four drops of laudanum.

4. Mr: Johnson continues very ill this day; though somewhat relieved from the violence of his last night’s symptoms. The child likewise continues sick— Dr: Thomas gave him an emetic—(ipecacuanha)— It operated twice, but I think did no good— At night he gave him four drops of laudanum again.— Mr: Johnson’s brother’s Thomas, James, and Baker, Mr: Graham, son in-Law to T. Johnson, and a son of Mr: James Johnson were all here. The family is very numerous, and the greater part of them live in this neighbourhood— I dined at Mr: Baker Johnson’s— Caroline, and the two youngest girls, went to their uncle T’s.— Mrs: Johnson was unwell too this evening.

5. Mr: Johnson still very ill. The child better— Went with Mrs: Adams and her sisters to Rose-hill, about a mile out of the town, and dined at Mr: Graham’s. Mr: T. Johnson lives with him. Mrs: Graham is his eldest daughter— There are two other daughters, Becca and Dorcas, and one son at home— Mrs: Graham is very ill and we did not see her— Becca is likewise in ill-health, with what they call here the chills and fever. Mr: Johnson had this evening a very severe fit of his illness— I watch’d with him this night.

6. Mr: Johnson a little better, but suffering yet violent pain at intervals— I removed with my family to Coll: Baker Johnson’s— The weather cleared up very cold, after the violent storm and rain of last night. I intended to have proceeded this morning upon my journey; but am detained in consequence of Mr: Johnson’s illness, and that of my child.

7. Waked between two and three this morning, by the child, and lost my rest the remainder of the night. Walk’d out this forenoon with Mr: T. Johnson to Rose-hill— Mrs: Adams came out with the child soon after, to stay the remainder of the time we are to pass here— The child is almost recovered.

8. Walk’d into town this morning with Mr: T. Johnson— Call’d at Coll: Baker’s, whose house is full with a family of his friends by the name of Goldsbury— Call’d on Mr: T. Johnson junr: the Governors eldest son— Return’d to dinner at Rose-hill— Mrs: Johnson came there to dinner, but return’d immediately after— In the evening I walk’d into town, and watch’d with my father in Law.

9. Walk’d out this morning and breakfasted at Rose-hill— Went to bed after breakfast, and rested a couple of hours— Becca Johnson has a relapse of the chills and fever.— I was very desirous to have continued our journey this morning, but Mr: Johnson’s illness is still so severe that we could not leave him.—

10. Walk’d with Mr: T. Johnson this morning in his garden— He shewed me the way to graft trees; and cut me off several slips of some remarkably fine pear-trees to take with me. Walk’d into town in the forenoon— Return’d to Rose-hill to dinner— The rain obliged me to ride— After dinner we took leave of Governor Johnson, Mr: Graham & the family, by whom we have been entertained with the most cordial and kind hospitality— We return’d to Mrs: Kimboll’s inn for the night— Went to Coll: Baker Johnson’s, and took leave of his family, and of his brother James— Caroline at length determined not to go with us; or rather Mrs: Johnson would not let her go— I wrote to Mr: Hellen the day before yesterday, requesting him to come here with Harriet in the stage this day— But they did not arrive.

11. At four o’clock this morning we left Frederic in the stage, and travell’d all day with great expedition; stopping only to change horses four times: once about half an hour to breakfast. The Roads are better than by the way of Baltimore— We came through the town of York, and soon after 5. P.M. reached the Susquehannah, having rode 70 miles. We cross’d the ferry in a very small boat— The river is so very low, and it was so dark that we were not without danger of running upon some of the numerous rocks that lie in the bed of the river.— At Columbia, on the eastern shore we stop’d to lodge. We had in our hurry left some of our things on the other side of the river— The ferryman went over and brought them to me.

12. At two o’clock this morning we left Columbia, and were alone in the stage 12 miles, to Lancaster. The rest of the way we had eight other passengers— The turnpike road is rather rougher than the other— We stop’d at Lancaster only to change horses before day-break, and could therefore see nothing of the place— The distance from Columbia to Philadelphia, is about 76 miles; we arrived at Mrs: Roberts’s—N. 139. Walnut street just at 5 in the afternoon— My brother soon after called upon us. Mrs: Adams was quite overcome by the fatigues of the journey, and in the evening was very ill.

13. Mrs: Adams appears this day to be much better— Call’d this morning upon my brother at his office; and rec’d from him several of my papers. Left with him only—The Pennsylvania bank stock, bridge shares, and J. P. Ripley’s note, with about 60 dollars. I went to the bank of the United States, to enquire if any document appeared, concerning Mr: Randolph’s payments to me in 1794— But found only the entry of 12. July.— In the afternoon I sat a couple of hours at my brother’s office with him and Mr: Dennie— We all went, and Mrs: A— to the play in the evening; where we saw Speed the plough, and Blue-beard.— Late home.

14. Pack’d up at my brother’s office, all my father’s dutch bonds and coupons; directed them to Messrs: Willink at Amsterdam—then went with him to the Coffee-house, and he delivered the packet to the bar-keeper, within the bar; to go in the letter bag of the ship Dispatch, Captainbound to Amsterdam, and about to sail— She belongs to Messrs: Pratt and Kinsing.— Wrote to my sister— Went to Dobson’s shop, for the 18th vol: of the Encyclopaedia— To the George-Inn and took seats in the Stage to New-York that goes on Monday— To William Cox the chair-maker’s 48 front street— Dined with Mr: Wykoff—Mr: Read, Meredith, M’Call, Dewitt, Dr: Cox and my brother there— Mrs: Adams very unwell all day; and so ill in the evening that I sent for Dr: Rush to see her— She is under great apprehensions, and still more depress’d in her spirits than really ill.

15— My brother called upon us this morning, and I took a walk with him— He dined with us. After dinner I went and sat with him in his office a couple of hours— Pass’d the evening in reading. Mrs: A— somewhat better.

16. Called this forenoon upon Mr: Dennie— Mrs: Rush with her son paid a visit to Mrs: Adams— At two o’clock afternoon we left Philadelphia in the stage (Commercial line) and came as far as Trenton— The roads begin already to be heavy from the late rains, and will soon be very deep— We arrived at Trenton, at about 8 in the evening.

17. Obliged to lodge all in one chamber; had a sleepless night, continually disturbed by the restlessness of the child. Soon after 4 o’clock in the morning we were called, and just at five resumed our seats in the stage. The roads grew worse the further we proceeded— We breakfasted at Princeton; dined at Elizabeth town, and at about 4 o’clock reached Gifford’s Inn at Newark. The distance we travell’d in the day, was 57. miles.— We left our baggage for the night at Gifford’s, and went ourselves to Mrs: Smith’s, who insisted upon our lodging at her house— We found her with only my brother Charles’s youngest daughter, Abigail, of her family— His widow, is upon a visit for a few days at New-York— The evening stormy, with copious rain.

18. At nine this morning we took Gifford’s stage, and rode nine miles to Powle’s hook.— The roads very bad, and will not soon be better— We have been remarkably fortunate to get thus far before they are entirely broken up.— Cross’d the ferry amidst the rain.— Met in the ferry boat Mr: James Jarvis an old acquaintance of mine— On landing at New-York, called an Hackney Coach, and came to Coll: Smith’s— He now lives at the Custom-house— Found his sister, my brother Charles’s widow there— I went upon Crane Wharf to enquire for Packets bound to Rhode-Island; found several, going in the course of four or five days— Return’d to the Colls: to dinner— Went in the evening to the play— Saw Fraternal Discord, a thing called a Comedy; the deepest dregs of democratic dulness— And the Prize, which amused us— It was almost Midnight, when we got home.

19. Went to the District Court, now sitting; but no cause of importance came on, and I had no opportunity to hear the celebrated orators of New-York— Went down to Crane Wharf, and engaged a passage for us on board the Cordelia Captain Anthony, bound to Providence— To sail to-morrow— Judge Hobart, dined with us at the Colls: In the evening I paid a visit to Mrs: Fitch— Return’d— My Sister had company for the Eveg:— Play’d whist, with her, Governor Crawford & Louisa.

20. Conversation this morning with Coll: Smith respecting his brother Justus’s note to me— Wrote him a letter— Went down to Crane Wharf and found the Cordelia was to sail in the afternoon— Call’d on Mr: M’Cormick, who went with me to the Colls: to see Louisa. Mr: W. Rogers, and the two Mr: Forbes’s call’d to see us. Rogers was married two days ago, to Mrs: Cruger— We dined early— Mr: James Jarvis dined at the Coll’s: with us. At 4 o’clock in the afternoon we were on board the Cordelia and cast off from the wharf, with a fair wind, but a light one. It died away so that we found some difficulty in rowing through hell-gate, at about 6. In the evening a breeze sprung up, but the wind was somewhat scanty— Weather very cold.

21. Had a fine breeze the first part of the day; but it died away about noon, and continued calm untill about sunset— The weather was very fine, though cold the whole day— As night approached it clouded up; began to snow and the wind came to the North-east. Captain Anthony was very apprehensive of a storm. At 8 in the evening he came to anchor in a little cove, under Fisher’s island, nearly opposite to New-London— Our passengers are Judge Robertson, Mr: French and Mr Pickering from the island of Tortola. A young frenchman from that of Guadeloupe, who comes here to learn the language a Mr: Troutnen, and a woman from New-York, whose name I have not heard— Dr: Bartlett of Newport is likewise one— And presented me copies of his treatise upon the pestilential fever, for my father and myself.

22. Snow’d almost all night, but without bad weather— Between 9 and 10 this morning, Captain Anthony with some hesitation from the fear of a storm again made sail— We laid our course, untill we reached point Judith, and thence beat up to Newport, where we arrived at 6 in the evening. I went ashore with my family and lodg’d at Mrs: Brenton’s— Dr: Bartlett left us here— The other passengers remain’d on board.

23. We sailed again from Newport this morning before 8 o’clock; but with adverse winds and calms, did not reach Providence untill 8 in the evening— Before we landed the drivers of two opposite lines of stages came on board, and contended for the preference of carrying us to Boston— We took the Mail-line, as the first comers.— In Providence we lodg’d at Aldrich’s.

24. At six this morning we started in the stage from Providence— Mr: Troutnen, the woman, and the young frenchman, with my family fill’d the stage. Judge Robertson and his companions remained to pass a day at Providence— We breakfasted at Attleborough— The frenchman left us at Wrentham— I went with him to Dr: Mann’s; where we found his friend Mr: Dureste— We dined at Dedham— There I saw the Sheriff of the County, Mr: Cutler, and a Committee of the Sessions, examining the gaol— I went over it with Mr: Cutler— It needs much alteration— We arrived in Boston between 3 and 4 in the afternoon—too late for the stage to Quincy— I endeavoured in vain to get a passage by a hackney Coach—but bespoke one for to-morrow— Saw Jo: Hall and Quincy— Call’d at Mr: Foster’s— We went to lodge at Mr: Smith’s as he had invited me— He was gone to inspect the Middlesex Canal, but returned in the evening— Rained just before we arrived in Boston, and all the remainder of the day.

25. Called in the morning upon Mrs: B. Shaw, to deliver the letter from her mother— She had not risen— Soon after 9 o’clock we left Mr: Smith’s, and came to Quincy, where we arrived just at noon; and thus happily completed the voyage and journey commenced on the 17th: of June— Here I had the pleasure of introducing my wife and child to my parents— With whom we spent the remainder of the day— Weather cold, but perfectly clear and fine— Miss Beale, and Miss called in the Evening.

26. Thanksgiving day— We attended the public worship in the forenoon— My Aunt Smith, T. Welsh, and W. Shaw dined with us. Mrs: Cranch called in the afternoon. My Uncle Adams and Captain Beale in the Evening. Weather remarkably beautiful.

27. Went with my mother down to my late uncle Quincy’s house, where there was an auction of some of his effects— I agreed to take some articles of the furniture, and purchased one or two books— We took my aunt Cranch home— Mrs: Guild and Mr: Crosby dined with us— They return’d in the afternoon to Cambridge. My mother and wife went in the afternoon again to the sale— My uncle Adams here in the evening.

28. Rose at 4. this morning— I wish to establish this as a common practise, from the time when I shall be settled at home; but am apprehensive I shall not be able to carry it through— I did but little however this day.— Wrote in the morning— Walk’d before dinner— Doctor Tufts dined with us— Walk’d in the afternoon with my wife— Mr: Greenleaf called in the evening.

29. Rose at 4. and bathed at the wharf below Mr: Black’s at 7 in the morning— Then took a walk. Attended meeting, twice— My old friend Mr: Ware of Hingham preached— He dined with us— In the evening we had a large company of visitors—My Uncle Adams’s family. Captn: Beale’s—Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf, and Mr: Thayer— Mr: and Mrs: Foster, from Boston, spend the night here.

30. Went to Boston with Louisa Smith— Went to the loan office with 8 per Ct: Stock to be registered— Am to call for it again.— To Quincy’s office— Letter and prints from Mr: Murray— To Mrs: Whitwell’s, and rec’d her last quarter’s rent. To Coll: Bradford’s— He hopes to quit the house in the week— Dined at Mr: Foster’s— Williams’s Court— Samuel Brookings, a troublesome client— Took a power of attorney from him at Hall’s— It was four before we could leave town; and very dark before we reach’d Quincy— My wife quite unwell.
Day. Irregular and unsettled— The principal part of the month travelling— Since arriving here, I am endeavouring to renew the practice of early rising—
